#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=2 .
#Text=System Model
#Text=2.1 .
#Text=Network Topology
#Text=Consider a mmWave cellular network consisting of base stations , blockages , and a source transmitter , which is a UE .
#Text=The UE attempts to connect to the N closest base stations , and therefore operates in a th order macrodiversity mode .
#Text=The locations of the base stations are modeled as an infinite homogeneous PPP with density .
#Text=We assume the centers of the blockages also form a homogeneous PPP with density , independent from the base station process .
#Text=Let indicate the source transmitter and its location .
#Text=Due to the stationarity of the PPPs , and without loss of generality , we can assume the coordinates are chosen such that the source transmitter is located at the origin ; i. e. , .
#Text=In Section 6 , we will consider additional transmitters located in neighboring cells , which act as interferers .
#Text=Let for i denote the base stations and their locations .
#Text=Let be the distance from to .
#Text=Base stations are ordered according to their distances to such that .
#Text=The signal of the source transmitter is received at the closest N base stations , and hence , N is the number of connected to .
#Text=For a PPP , a derivation of the distribution of is given in Appendix B , which implies a methodology for generating these distances within a simulation .
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=shows an example of second-order macrodiversity ( ) cellular network where the user attempts to connect to its closest two base stations .
#Text=The solid line indicates the link from the user to the base station is LOS , while the dashed line indicates the link is NLOS .
#Text=The figure shows examples of two different blockage scenarios .
#Text=In
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=a the closest base station ( ) is LOS while is NLOS to the user , in which case the blockage only blocks a single link .
#Text=In
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=b a single blockage blocks both links to and .
#Text=The fact that sometimes a single blockage can block both links is an illustration of the effect of correlated blocking .
#Text=2.2 .
#Text=Blockage Model
#Text=As in , each blockage is a segment of length W .
#Text=To capture the worst-case scenario , as shown in
#Text=Figure 2
#Text=a , it is assumed that the line representing the blockage is perpendicular to the line that connects it to the transmitter .
#Text=Although W can itself be random as in , we assume here that all blockages have the same value of W .
#Text=In
#Text=Figure 2
#Text=a , the red stars indicate the blocked base stations , which are located in the blue shaded region .
#Text=If a blockage cuts the path from to , then the signal from is NLOS , while otherwise it is LOS .
#Text=Here , we assume that NLOS signals are completely blocked while LOS signals experience exponential path-loss with a path-loss exponent ; i. e. , the power received by is proportional to .
#Text=Each base station has a blockage region associated with it , illustrated by the blue shaded rectangles shown in
#Text=Figure 2
#Text=b. We use to denote the blockage region associated with and its area ; i. e. , is both a region and an area .
#Text=If the center of a blockage falls within , then will be blocked since at least some part of the blockage will intersect the path between and .
#Text=Because is a rectangle of length and width W , it is clear that .
#Text=Unless and are exactly on opposite sides of the region , there will be an overlapping region v common to both and .
#Text=Because of the overlap , it is possible for a single blockage to simultaneously block both and if the blockage falls within region v , which corresponds to correlated blocking .
